awd_titl_txt: IRCN:  Coordinating research on bark beetle - fungal interactions in South Africa and the U.S.
awd_abstract_narration:
Forests and tree industries around the world are increasingly threatened by invasive pests and diseases, such as wood boring bark beetles and their associated fungi.  A better understanding of the mutually beneficial -- or symbiotic -- relationship between bark beetles and fungi is critical for the long-term health and sustainability of global forests. Currently, however, bark beetle-fungal symbioses are poorly understood resulting in a limited number of strategies to control both the spread and impact of bark beetles in forests worldwide.  This International Research Coordination Network (IRCN) project, co-funded by the U.S. National Science Foundation (NSF) and South African National Research Foundation (NRF), will coordinate the research activities of forest pathologists, entomologists and mycologists throughout South Africa and the U.S. -- two of the world's most productive forest health research communities.  The IRCN will connect 14 institutions, represented by 22 individual researchers, to critically assess how bark beetles and their fungal associates are currently studied and how this research could be improved.  U.S. and South African undergraduates and graduate students will be trained broadly as part of a laboratory exchange program to enhance research coordination between the two countries.  More than half of the project participants are under-represented in science, including females, minorities, and early-career scientists. Natural resource managers and the public will be engaged to help formulate better management strategies based on newly synthesized data among the network members, and information on bark beetle - fungal symbioses will be disseminated broadly via online videos and other media.  

This U.S. - South African IRCN project aims to re-evaluate, invigorate and coordinate research on bark beetle - fungus symbioses. Specific aims of the Network include adoption of new data standards to improve mobility of vector-fungus association data, and enhanced sharing of databases among established repositories to facilitate synthesis of diverse bark beetle and fungal data.  Exchanges among participating laboratories will facilitate the introduction of new technologies across the Research Network and help reconcile conflicting bark beetle - fungal symbiosis paradigms. The Network will also maintain a publicly available social media portal discussing research on bark beetle/fungal symbioses and publish a synthesis for the global community of researchers studying symbioses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this International Research Coordination Network was to intensify and improve research on the interactions between bark beetles (important wood boring insects) and fungi. These organisms are important for basic research as a model of symbiosis, but also for applied research, tree health, and biosecurity because many beetle-fungus pairs cause tree death, sometimes at large scales. This project aimed at improving collaboration between the two major research communities that study this insect-fungus-tree system: the American and South African. Our specific goals included 1) improving data availability (as opposed to keeping data within labs), facilitating the use of new technologies, and adopting and publishing data standards.

We had four in-person meetings, each of which resulted in a tangible result. The first and the last of the meetings each yielded a substantial publication aimed at summarizing the current state of research, and charting a path forward, with recommendations and standards that will lead to more robust research in this field. Additional outcomes of the in-person meeting include the testing of several digital platforms for recording data in the field. One of the meetings was turned into a training of entomologists and mycologists on bark beetle identification and systematics with focus on Africa, which resulted in the publication of a Catalog of South African bark beetles.

We also held 14 online meetings, all of which were public. Each was attended not only by the many labs involved in this project, but also by colleagues and students from many teams around the world. Some of the most significant online meetings included guests from inspiring or technologically advanced labs (the audience was introduced to advances in molecular mycology), guests from regulatory agencies (both US and South African), and guest from teams that focus on the “real world” impact and management of the beetle-fungus-tree system. For faculty and students alike, these encounters have shifted our understanding of the significance of this research topic, and the need to develop its robustness and reliability (statistical and data standards), because scientists, governments and tree industries all rely on our data.

One of the goals was also to increase the transparency and openness of this field, therefore the Network maintained a social media portal and a website with recordings and summaries from all meetings, and published two research syntheses: one at the beginning of the project, and final at the end.
